Fun Facts about the Elements

Gold (Au) is so dense that 1 cubic foot weighs ~1,206 lbs (~547 kg).

Oxygen (O) makes up 21% of Earth’s atmosphere.

Hydrogen (H) is the most abundant element in the universe.

Carbon (C) is the basis for all known life on Earth.

Helium (He) is the second most abundant element in the universe.

Iron (Fe) is the most common element on Earth by mass.

Who Invented the Periodic Table

  • Dmitri Mendeleev (1834–1907) created the first widely recognized periodic table in 1869.
  • Arranged 63 known elements by atomic mass, spotting patterns in their properties.
  • Predicted undiscovered elements like Gallium and Germanium accurately.

Fun Fact: Mendeleev initially used cardboard cards to arrange elements.

History of the Periodic Table

Early Attempts

1800–1860s
  • Scientists like Dmitri Dobereiner grouped elements into “triads” based on properties.
  • John Newlands (1864) proposed the Law of Octaves, noting patterns every 8 elements.

Mendeleev’s Breakthrough

1869
  • First systematic, predictive periodic table.
  • Organized elements by atomic mass with periodic trends in chemical properties.

Modern Table

1913–1950s
  • Henry Moseley (1913) reordered elements by atomic number, resolving inconsistencies.
  • Discovery of noble gases (1890s) and actinides/lanthanides expanded the table.
  • The modern table now has 7 periods and 18 groups, including synthetic elements like Oganesson (Og, 118).

Latest News & Discoveries

2023Source

Scientists confirmed new isotopes of superheavy elements, expanding research on the “island of stability.”

2022Source

Research shows Carbon-based materials like graphene may revolutionize electronics and energy storage.

2021Source

Nobel Prize awarded for advances in quantum chemistry, helping predict properties of unknown elements.

Ongoing

Educational platforms now integrate interactive 3D periodic tables, helping students explore trends visually.

Fun Fact: Despite being over 150 years old, the periodic table remains a living document, with new elements synthesized and discoveries constantly refining our understanding of matter.
